00:00:01:080000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:00:01:080000.Dialogue: Good evening. I'm your guest lecturer, Dr. Sheldon Cooper.

00:00:10:160000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:00:10:160000.Dialogue: I was expecting applause, but I suppose stunned silence is equally appropriate. I agreed to speak to you this evening, because I was told that you're the best and the brightest of this university's doctoral candidates. Hmm. Of course, that's like saying you are the most important electron in a hydrogen atom.

00:00:36:030000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:00:36:030000.Dialogue: Cause, you see, there's only one electron in a hydrogen atom.

00:00:43:000000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:00:43:000000.Dialogue: Best and brightest, my sweet patootie. All right, let's begin. Show of hands, who here is familiar with the concept of topological insulators? Don't kid yourselves.

00:00:57:020000.Speaker: Leonard
00:00:57:020000.Dialogue: I found another tweet from a student at Sheldon's lecture. Dr. Cooper has taken a relatively boring subject and managed to make it completely insufferable. Plus, he looks like a giant insect."

00:01:10:000000.Speaker: Howard
00:01:10:000000.Dialogue: Look. Listen to this one. Does Einstein's theory explain why time flies when you're having fun, but when you're listening to Dr. Cooper, it falls out of the sky, dead?

00:01:20:230000.Speaker: Raj
00:01:20:230000.Dialogue: Ooh, somebody took pictures and uploaded them to their Flickr account.

00:01:25:040000.Speaker: Leonard
00:01:25:040000.Dialogue: Wow. How do you get an entire lecture hall to flip you off at the same time?

00:01:30:150000.Speaker: Howard
00:01:30:150000.Dialogue: Apparently, if you're Sheldon, all you need to do is turn your back.

00:01:34:180000.Speaker: Penny
00:01:34:180000.Dialogue: Hey, Leonard, is your wi-fi down? I can't get on.

00:01:38:110000.Speaker: Leonard
00:01:38:110000.Dialogue: Oh, Sheldon changed the password. It's now "Penny is a freeloader."

00:01:44:130000.Speaker: Penny
00:01:44:130000.Dialogue: Thanks. What are you guys doing?

00:01:46:140000.Speaker: Leonard
00:01:46:140000.Dialogue: Sheldon gave a lecture at the university tonight. We're reading the reviews.

00:01:50:230000.Speaker: Howard
00:01:50:230000.Dialogue: Well, picture the Hindenburg meets Chernobyl meets Three Mile Island meets Tron 2.

00:02:00:050000.Speaker: Penny
00:02:00:050000.Dialogue: Listening to Dr. Cooper has made me want to start cutting myself again

00:02:08:090000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:02:08:090000.Dialogue: Good evening, Leonard, Howard, Raj, freeloader.

00:02:16:050000.Speaker: Leonard
00:02:16:050000.Dialogue: In a word, triumphant. Really? Triumphant?

00:02:22:080000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:02:22:080000.Dialogue: Oh, yes, you should have seen those young people. Thirsty for knowledge, drinking in my wisdom. I may have changed a few lives today.

00:02:30:120000.Speaker: Penny
00:02:30:120000.Dialogue: Oh, please let me tell him.

00:02:34:160000.Speaker: Leonard
00:02:34:160000.Dialogue: I don't know, I kind of promised Howard.

00:02:38:110000.Speaker: Howard
00:02:38:110000.Dialogue: Actually, we should all share the moment. Raj, if you would.

00:02:49:070000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:02:49:070000.Dialogue: Hmm... That's rather unfair. That's downright cruel. Plus, insects have six legs.

00:03:00:220000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:03:00:220000.Dialogue: Yeah, I'm not familiar with the acronym KMN

00:03:03:170000.Speaker: Leonard
00:03:03:170000.Dialogue: From the context, we think it means "kill me now.

00:03:10:100000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:03:10:100000.Dialogue: Well, I suppose everyone's entitled to their own opinion. I think I'll turn in. I didn't want to teach those poopy heads, anyway.

00:03:23:210000.Speaker: Howard
00:03:23:210000.Dialogue: FYI, I think that's what Darth Vader said just before he started building the Death Star.

00:03:56:030000.Speaker: Leonard
00:03:56:030000.Dialogue: Yeah, it's weird. Even though he didn't want to give the lecture in the first place, being rejected by those students really hit him hard.

00:04:01:030000.Speaker: Raj
00:04:01:030000.Dialogue: I know the feeling. It's like accidentally walking into a gay bar and then having no one hit on you.

00:04:12:220000.Speaker: Raj
00:04:12:220000.Dialogue: It-It happened to a friend of mine.

00:04:19:200000.Speaker: Howard
00:04:19:200000.Dialogue: Leonard and I are fine, but I think Raj needs to meet a girl really soon.

00:04:24:230000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:04:24:230000.Dialogue: Well, that shouldn't be too hard. He's such a cutie.

00:04:27:060000.Speaker: Raj
00:04:27:060000.Dialogue: Thank you, but "cute" is for bunnies. I want to be something with sex appeal, like... like a labradoodle.

00:04:37:070000.Speaker: Leonard
00:04:37:070000.Dialogue: We might be starting to zero in on your problem.

00:04:41:060000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:04:41:060000.Dialogue: Don't you listen to them. You've got plenty of sex appeal.

00:04:47:020000.Speaker: Raj
00:04:47:020000.Dialogue: Well, thanks, Bernadette. And just for the record, labradoodles are hypo-allergenic, which is a very sexy quality to those troubled by animal dander.

00:05:00:230000.Speaker: Amy
00:05:00:230000.Dialogue: AMY So, what do you think?

00:05:05:050000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:05:05:050000.Dialogue: It's a charming illusion, but it does not cheer me up.

00:05:08:220000.Speaker: Amy
00:05:08:220000.Dialogue: Not even when I do this?

00:05:19:120000.Speaker: Amy
00:05:19:120000.Dialogue: Well, that was the last arrow in my quiver of whimsy.

00:05:24:050000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:05:24:050000.Dialogue: Do you realize that teaching is the first thing I've failed at since my ill-fated attempt to complete a chin-up in March of 1989?

00:05:31:170000.Speaker: Amy
00:05:31:170000.Dialogue: If this humiliating experience is really troubling you, there are things we could do about it.

00:05:38:010000.Speaker: Amy
00:05:38:010000.Dialogue: Well, the first thing that comes to mind is isolating the part of your brain where the memory is stored and destroying it with a laser.

00:05:44:190000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:05:44:190000.Dialogue: Hmm, no. One slip of the hand, and suddenly I'm sitting in the Engineering Department, building doodads with Wolowitz.

00:05:53:100000.Speaker: Amy
00:05:53:100000.Dialogue: All right. Have you considered improving your socialization skills, thus allowing you to communicate more effectively with other people?

00:06:00:090000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:06:00:090000.Dialogue: Isn't that their burden? I'm the one with something interesting to say.

00:06:04:230000.Speaker: Amy
00:06:04:230000.Dialogue: Fair enough, but in its essence, teaching is a performance art. In the classroom paradigm, the teacher has the responsibility to communicate, as well as entertain and engage.

00:06:15:040000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:06:15:040000.Dialogue: I sense that you're trying to slow-walk me to an epiphany. Would you mind very much jumping to it?

00:06:20:110000.Speaker: Amy
00:06:20:110000.Dialogue: Perhaps you should consider taking acting lessons.

00:06:23:230000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:06:23:230000.Dialogue: Acting lessons. Interesting. It might help if I could act as though I care about my students and whether or not they learn.

00:06:45:110000.Speaker: Penny
00:06:45:110000.Dialogue: I'm not an "actress." I'm an actress.

00:06:55:070000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:06:55:070000.Dialogue: I need you to teach me.

00:06:58:030000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:06:58:030000.Dialogue: Perhaps two. I'd like to master the craft.

00:07:01:080000.Speaker: Penny
00:07:01:080000.Dialogue: Okay, where is this coming from?

00:07:04:040000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:07:04:040000.Dialogue: It has been suggested to me that acting techniques could improve my lecturing, at which, if certain tweets and blogs are to be believed, I "suck the big one."

00:07:14:060000.Speaker: Penny
00:07:14:060000.Dialogue: Yeah, I saw those. They were funny. I printed a few out and put 'em on my fridge.

00:07:21:190000.Speaker: Penny
00:07:21:190000.Dialogue: Okay, just to be clear. You are asking me for help because I know something that the brilliant Dr. Sheldon Cooper doesn't.

00:07:28:180000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:07:28:180000.Dialogue: I suppose that's one way to look at it.

00:07:32:130000.Speaker: Penny
00:07:32:130000.Dialogue: I think it's the only way to look at it.

00:07:35:080000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:07:35:080000.Dialogue: Are you going to help me or not?

00:07:37:050000.Speaker: Penny
00:07:37:050000.Dialogue: Probably. I'm just enjoying the foreplay.

00:07:40:200000.Speaker: Penny
00:07:40:200000.Dialogue: Does this mean you are done mocking my acting career?

00:07:43:060000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:07:43:060000.Dialogue: Oh, I'm sorry, I thought making the transition from actor to acting teacher was the signal that one's career had reached the end of the road.

00:08:03:230000.Speaker: Howard
00:08:03:230000.Dialogue: I just got offered a fellowship at the Weitzmann Institute in Israel.

00:08:11:230000.Speaker: Raj
00:08:11:230000.Dialogue: Aw, I'm gonna miss you. Are you going with him?

00:08:14:210000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:08:14:210000.Dialogue: I have to stay here for school.

00:08:16:190000.Speaker: Howard
00:08:16:190000.Dialogue: That's what we're here to talk to you about. You see, Bernadette has needs.

00:08:29:070000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:08:29:070000.Dialogue: Most of them regular, some of them kind of messed up.

00:08:35:220000.Speaker: Howard
00:08:35:220000.Dialogue: So, while I'm gone, you're going to have to satisfy her.

00:08:51:200000.Speaker: Howard
00:08:51:200000.Dialogue: What ya thinking so hard about?

00:08:54:150000.Speaker: Raj
00:08:54:150000.Dialogue: Just that I'm definitely not gay.

00:09:17:090000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:09:17:090000.Dialogue: Yes. In preparation for today's studies, I read Stanislavski's An Actor Prepares, Stella Adler's The Technique of Acting, Uta Hagen's Respect for Acting, and Henry Winkler's Ayyy, I'm an Actor.

00:09:29:050000.Speaker: Penny
00:09:29:050000.Dialogue: Well, good for you. Come on in.

00:09:34:040000.Speaker: Penny
00:09:34:040000.Dialogue: Well, I thought we'd start with some basic movement exercises. You know, get our bodies warmed up a little.

00:09:41:100000.Speaker: Penny
00:09:41:100000.Dialogue: So I just want you to relax and kind of move around in the space. You know, just do whatever feels natural.

00:09:55:200000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:09:55:200000.Dialogue: You said to do whatever feels natural. This feels natural.

00:10:01:060000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:10:01:060000.Dialogue: Certainly more natural than what you're doing.

00:10:04:080000.Speaker: Penny
00:10:04:080000.Dialogue: Come on, you got to work with me. We need to get connected with our bodies.

00:10:07:080000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:10:07:080000.Dialogue: Penny, my body and I have a relationship that works best when we maintain a cool, wary distance from each other.

00:10:16:230000.Speaker: Penny
00:10:16:230000.Dialogue: All right, let's just say we've warmed up.

00:10:23:030000.Speaker: Penny
00:10:23:030000.Dialogue: Okay. One of the things that might help you in connecting with your students is being a little more spontaneous. So why don't we try some improvisation?

00:10:30:180000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:10:30:180000.Dialogue: Why not? It seems like you're improvising your entire curriculum.

00:10:36:150000.Speaker: Penny
00:10:36:150000.Dialogue: This is all about listening and responding.

00:10:40:080000.Speaker: Penny
00:10:40:080000.Dialogue: I'm going to create a character and a situation, and you just jump in when you feel it.

00:10:48:150000.Speaker: Penny
00:10:48:150000.Dialogue: Okay, it's not a movie. It's improv. So no one calls "action."

00:10:59:060000.Speaker: Penny
00:10:59:060000.Dialogue: Okay. Uh, no, the shipment has not arrived, and I really need those shoes. They are my biggest seller. Yes, ladies sizes six through ten. Thank you. Oh, sorry. I have to go. I have a customer. Bye-bye. Hi. Can I help you?

00:11:11:230000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:11:11:230000.Dialogue: I'd like a frozen yogurt, please.

00:11:19:140000.Speaker: Penny
00:11:19:140000.Dialogue: Um... Okay, sure. Luckily, we sell both shoes and yogurt here.

00:11:30:060000.Speaker: Penny
00:11:30:060000.Dialogue: Yes. Look up at the sign, and remember, improv is always about saying yes.

00:11:40:040000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:11:40:040000.Dialogue: I see a sign. It says "Camarillo State Mental Hospital."

00:11:48:140000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:11:48:140000.Dialogue: It's the only explanation I can come up with for why you think you sell shoes and yogurt.

00:11:54:130000.Speaker: Penny
00:11:54:130000.Dialogue: Okay, you know what? Let's just try a different improv. Uh.. Oh, this time we will be two winos living under a freeway overpass.

00:12:02:200000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:12:02:200000.Dialogue: Oh, and we're going to use props?

00:12:08:220000.Speaker: Penny
00:12:08:220000.Dialogue: I had dreams, you know. I was gonna be famous. Show everybody back home I could be someone. Now look at me. Want some?

00:12:23:230000.Speaker: Leonard
00:12:23:230000.Dialogue: I'm still not adjusted to how the SyFy channel spells their name now. S-y-F-y. That's "siffy."

00:12:38:080000.Speaker: Leonard
00:12:38:080000.Dialogue: Hello? Oh, my God! Is he okay?

00:12:43:210000.Speaker: Leonard
00:12:43:210000.Dialogue: Hang on. Hang on. Uh-huh. Okay, thank you. Howard was on his scooter, and got hit by a truck. He's in critical condition.

00:12:58:140000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:12:58:140000.Dialogue: Did you hear? Isn't it terrible?

00:13:02:200000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:13:02:200000.Dialogue: They wouldn't let me in. Oh, my Howie.

00:13:07:010000.Speaker: Leonard
00:13:07:010000.Dialogue: It'll be okay. It'll be okay.

00:13:10:150000.Speaker: Raj
00:13:10:150000.Dialogue: It'll be okay. It'll be okay. It's Howard. Howard, hello.

00:13:24:230000.Speaker: Raj
00:13:24:230000.Dialogue: Yeah, I'm right here, buddy. How are you?

00:13:26:200000.Speaker: Howard
00:13:26:200000.Dialogue: Shh, shh. Listen to me. I'm not gonna make it.

00:13:29:220000.Speaker: Raj
00:13:29:220000.Dialogue: No, no, no, don't say that. You're going to be all right.

00:13:33:000000.Speaker: Howard
00:13:33:000000.Dialogue: Raj, I don't have time. Now, pay attention. My last wish is that you look after Bernadette.

00:13:40:070000.Speaker: Raj
00:13:40:070000.Dialogue: Of course, of course. Now when you say "look after," you mean...

00:13:48:180000.Speaker: Raj
00:13:48:180000.Dialogue: Excuse me, Bernadette. I have to hear it from him.

00:13:58:050000.Speaker: Raj
00:13:58:050000.Dialogue: I guess I have no choice but to make sweet, guilt-free love to you over and over again for the rest of my life.

00:14:23:180000.Speaker: Penny
00:14:23:180000.Dialogue: So, did you get a chance to go over the scene I gave you?

00:14:25:210000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:14:25:210000.Dialogue: Yes. I didn't care for it.

00:14:29:200000.Speaker: Penny
00:14:29:200000.Dialogue: Okay, Cat on a Hot Tin Roof is an American classic.

00:14:34:010000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:14:34:010000.Dialogue: So is the McRib sandwich. I don't care for that, either.

00:14:39:210000.Speaker: Penny
00:14:39:210000.Dialogue: Fine. What would you rather do as a scene study?

00:14:43:050000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:14:43:050000.Dialogue: I'm glad you asked. I took the liberty of adapting a Star Trek fan fiction novella I wrote when I was ten into a one-act play.

00:14:52:080000.Speaker: Penny
00:14:52:080000.Dialogue: And you think it's better than Tennessee Williams?

00:14:55:180000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:14:55:180000.Dialogue: Why don't we leave that for future generations to decide?

00:14:59:180000.Speaker: Penny
00:14:59:180000.Dialogue: Where No Sheldon Has Gone Before.

00:15:03:170000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:15:03:170000.Dialogue: It's the story of a young boy who is transported from the ignorant backwoods of East Texas to the 23rd Century, where his genius is not only appreciated, but celebrated.

00:15:19:230000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:15:19:230000.Dialogue: Now, in this pivotal scene, Sheldon's mother, played by you, argues with an emissary of the United Federation of Planets, Mr. Spock, the role I will bring to life.

00:15:31:060000.Speaker: Penny
00:15:31:060000.Dialogue: Okay, that's fine, but let's try and get you out of your comfort zone.

00:15:35:200000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:15:35:200000.Dialogue: Why would we want to do that? It's called "the comfort zone" for a reason.

00:15:40:100000.Speaker: Penny
00:15:40:100000.Dialogue: Okay, the whole point of this is to loosen you up a little, so I'm thinking you'll play the role of your mother, and I will bring life to Mr. Spock.

00:16:02:180000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:16:02:180000.Dialogue: Very well. I'll set the scene.

00:16:06:220000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:16:06:220000.Dialogue: East Texas. A warm summer night. A woman, Mary, stands on a porch. In the distance, we hear a lonesome train whistle..." The droning buzz of cicadas.." A coyote howls at the moon, frightening sensitive young boys everywhere." Out in the woods, an owl screeches...

00:16:31:100000.Speaker: Penny
00:16:31:100000.Dialogue: Okay, okay. We get it. You set the scene.

00:16:37:210000.Speaker: Penny
00:16:37:210000.Dialogue: Now just read your mother's line.

00:16:42:140000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:16:42:140000.Dialogue: Shelly! Shelly, how many times have I told you not to leave your sciencey stuff out on the porch? Goodness, I'll never understand that boy. But then again, I'm a religious nut, and my mind is closed to so many things."

00:17:08:120000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:17:08:120000.Dialogue: Glory be to Heaven, some sort of creature just manifested out of thin air. George, put down that Pepsi can full of bourbon that ain't foolin' no one, and get your shotgun!

00:17:20:050000.Speaker: Penny
00:17:20:050000.Dialogue: Greetings, Mary Cooper. I am Spock.

00:17:27:110000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:17:27:110000.Dialogue: I'm sorry. I just don't buy it.

00:17:33:140000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:17:33:140000.Dialogue: Oh, my, your sudden appearance startles me.

00:17:37:200000.Speaker: Penny
00:17:37:200000.Dialogue: We have been monitoring your son Sheldon from the 23rd Century, and we have determined that he is now ready to join us. His unique genius is our best hope for bringing peace to a vast and troubled galaxy.

00:17:49:060000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:17:49:060000.Dialogue: I understand. Oh, Shelly? A man's here to take you away to the future! Be sure to pack clean underwear.

00:17:58:140000.Speaker: Penny
00:17:58:140000.Dialogue: Okay, okay, let's try that last line again, and this time, maybe try choking up a little.

00:18:05:170000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:18:05:170000.Dialogue: Yes, but he's going to a better place where he won't get beat up... so much.

00:18:11:060000.Speaker: Penny
00:18:11:060000.Dialogue: All right, come on, just try it my way. Pretend you're sad to see him go. I'm gonna lead you in. His unique genius is our best hope for bringing peace to a vast and troubled galaxy. - That's your cue.

00:18:24:010000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:18:24:010000.Dialogue: - I'm sorry. I just love that line.

00:18:28:040000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:18:28:040000.Dialogue: Even the way you do it.

00:18:30:180000.Speaker: Penny
00:18:30:180000.Dialogue: All right, come on, come on. Put some real emotion into it. Blah-blah, blah, blah... "vast and troubled galaxy." Go. Hmm.

00:18:37:190000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:18:37:190000.Dialogue: Oh, Shelly? A man's here to take you away to the future"

00:18:46:080000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:18:46:080000.Dialogue: Be sure to pack clean underwear."

00:18:49:010000.Speaker: Penny
00:18:49:010000.Dialogue: That's good. That's good. That's good.

00:18:52:060000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:18:52:060000.Dialogue: Mommy, why are you crying? Cause I'm gonna miss you, Shelly-bean, even though you creep the bugeeses out of me.

00:19:01:080000.Speaker: Penny
00:19:01:080000.Dialogue: Okay, I guess we're improvising now.

00:19:03:050000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:19:03:050000.Dialogue: I'm sorry. It's not my fault. I'm just incredibly smart, and everyone around here is dumber than a bag of rocks. Oh, now, don't you start crying. You get in that spaceship. Mommy's late for Indian bingo.

00:19:19:200000.Speaker: Penny
00:19:19:200000.Dialogue: Mrs. Cooper, hey, it's Penny. Yeah, I think I broke your son. Hey, hold on. Talk to your mother.

00:19:27:010000.Speaker: Sheldon
00:19:27:010000.Dialogue: Mommy, I love you. Don't let Spock take me to the future!

00:19:38:200000.Speaker: Bernadette
00:19:38:200000.Dialogue: Okay, Raj, I know you've been avoiding me and Howard, and I'm not leaving until you tell me what's going on inside that little head of yours.

00:20:56:120000.Speaker: Raj
00:20:56:120000.Dialogue: Dance number aside, I'm so not gay.
